March 11, 2013

Evaluation For: Mark Nieman
Recommender: Frederick J. Boehmke

Dear Selection Committee Member,

I am pleased to write this letter in support of Mark Nieman’s application for the 2013 Political Methodology Summer Meeting. As a faculty member at the University of Iowa I have had Nieman in three of my methods classes and can say that he is currently one our best graduate students in methods. Nieman is in his fifth year in the program and has taken three courses from me, attended the methods conference last summer, and took Curt Signorino’s EITM-style course at the Essex Summer School in Social Science Data Analysis a couple years ago. He plans to defend his PhD this spring or summer, so would likely no longer be a graduate student by the time the meeting rolls around. 

Last year, Nieman presented a paper that relates to work from his dissertation that develops a censored strategic probit analysis. While conflict data generally differentiate between cases in which revisionists claims are made and acceded to by the target and cases in which no claim is made, such information does not exist for civil wars. This makes it impossible to directly estimate a strategic probit model. Nieman modified the strategic probit model to account for this lack of information in the data and has Monte Carlo evidence and the substantive application. His proposal this year seeks to present an improved version of this new estimator that addresses some biases that emerged in the original version and that provides a new empirical application. This is a very nice paper that develops a new estimator in order to address an interesting substantive question. 

I believe that Nieman would benefit greatly from the opportunity to attend the summer methods meeting. He has progressed quite well since attending last year and has incorporated feedback he received into his research, which has led to its improvement, and also plans to defend his dissertation in the near future. He will likely be on the job market this fall, so this would be a particularly fortuitous time for him to attend the meeting. He has also developed into a good methodologist in general and I believe he would be able to contribute to the conversation in general and offer useful comments on others’ work as well.

Please let me know if you any questions.

Frederick J. Boehmke

recommendation:
Felipe is a very talented student engaged in an interesting thesis project.  He has extensive training in statistics and his earning his Masters in Statistics in addition to his PhD in Political Science.  

He is developing a very interesting Bayesian latent class model which he will apply to allocations of federal social welfare spending to municipalities made by presidents in Argentina, Brazil, and Mexico.  These allocations are left-censored (many municipalities are provided no support) and  right-skewed (a few municipalities receive very large allocations in total and per capita).  There is also considerable stickiness in these allocations over time and probably other source of heterogeneity that must be accounted for as well.  Felipe develops a clever model that links comparative statics derived from a formal model of these allocations to parameters of his Bayesian latent class model.

Felipe is a rising star in our department.  I think he is as strong as any of the recent excellent students of comparative politics that we have produced.  I very much hope that he can be afforded the opportunity to present at Methods this summer.

Jack Pain is one of the best graduate students at Berkeley right now. He is energetic and talented.  His proposed poster presentation is based on at least two years of work on understanding the uses and limitations of cross-national regression in comparative politics. He notes that while scholars running such regressions are increasingly attentive to issues related to causal inference, they almost always fail to address a key confounder for many national level treatment variables: geographical concentration. Because this often leads to actual or near violations of common support conditions, controlling for potential confounders in a parametric regression often fails to hold constant the effect of a posited confounder. In his proposed presentation, he looks at three popular treatment variables in comparative politics: the effects of oil, Western colonial experience, and having a larger percentage of Muslims. He finds that the oil result holds up, notwithstanding the concerns about geographic concentration. However, he finds that after properly accounting for geographical concentration, the strong global sample correlations between each of short Western colonial experience and large Muslim populations with a lack of democracy are spurious.

This work represents careful attention to both the data and the properties of regression estimators (e.g., influence curves and leverage points). It is very interesting work.

recommendation:
March 6, 2013

To Whom It May Concern::

I am pleased to recommend Srinivas “Chinnu” Parinandi for for the Political Methodology meeting. Chinnu is a terrific student and is off to an excellent start on his dissertation.  I am confident that he would make a strong presentation at the meeting; and know that in turn he will get some extremely helpful feedback on his project.

Chinnu has been a terrific student in our program, earning top grades and even earning a rare “pass with distinction” on his American politics preliminary exam.  More relevant here is that he is now working diligently on his dissertation, in which he takes a new and innovative approach to the study of policy diffusion by distinguishing between imitation and innovation.  A legislature in one state might simply adopt the same exact policy that legislatures in other states have adopted.  That is, it imitates the actions of those earlier states.  Another state legislature, however, might adopt a policy that, although roughly similar to the policy found in other states, also differs in substantial ways. As Chinnu points out, this is not imitation; it’s innovation. And those are two very different things. Yet virtually every scholar of policy diffusion has lumped these two types of processes – imitation and innovation – together, often having a simple dependent variable that is coded as “1” if a state legislature adopts a policy that another state legislature previously adopted, regardless of whether the state adopts the exact same policy found elsewhere (i.e., imitation) or adopts a policy that addresses the same issue but does so in an entirely different way (i.e., innovation).  

In his dissertation, Chinnu sets out to explain why some state legislatures innovate, while others imitate.  This is a surprisingly thorny question, both theoretically and empirically.  Theoretically, you need to be able to explain why states would prefer one approach to the other, or why even a single state might prefer to innovate in some policy areas, or at some times, and to imitate in others. In his theoretical explanation, he identifies the factors that strike me as exactly the right ones to focus on – the greater risk that is inherent in innovating (and which types of state legislators are more willing to take on, or be fearful of, such risk); the pressures created by upcoming elections (and the worries about adopting an innovation that backfires just prior to such elections); the capacity of legislatures in some states to be more certain about the effects of innovative policies; whether control of government is divided or unified (and this whether different branches are likely to be able to agree on significant innovations); and so on.  Much of the research on policy diffusion has been empirical, rather than theoretical.  Thus, Chinnu’s theoretical work promises to make a significant contribution to our understanding of this process.

The empirical aspect is just as important and just as thorny.  Basically, some laws are clear imitations, where a state legislature simply writes down, almost word for word, a law found in another state, and adopts that earlier law.  Other policies are clear innovations – for example, when a state adopts a law that addresses the same policy area as that found in a different state, but the new law differs in significant ways from the earlier law.  Those are the easy cases; the difficulty lies with coding all the laws that lie between those two poles.  Chinnu has worked extremely hard over the past few months to come up with a way of distinguishing imitation from innovation, and has found two creative ways to do it.  First, he focuses on a specific policy area that many state legislatures are addressing – deriving energy from renewable sources – and has developed a way to code each aspect of this policy area (e.g., the mechanism that the state uses for setting and enforcing standards; the rates that each law establishes; and so on).  Based on this approach, he can determine the extent to which a law adopted in one state differs from laws previously adopted in other states.  Second, using computer programs that allow for comparisons of different documents, he can calculate a continuous measure of the difference between a law adopted in one state and a law adopted earlier in another.  Both of these measures, then, allow him to test his theoretical argument and to disentangle imitation and innovation.

For the Methods meeting, Chinnu plans to present a poster of the empirical strategy that he is using in his dissertation.  That is, he’ll present the coding strategy he’s employing, along with details of the computer-based comparison (in which he relies on anti-plagiarism software).  The goal will be to provide an empirical test, using these methods, of the arguments he lays out in his theoretical chapter.  He’ll do an excellent job of this, and as a result, I’m happy to endorse his application for the meeting. 

Sincerely,


Charles R. Shipan
Chair, Department of Political Science 
J. Ira and Nicki Harris Professor of Social Science

March 6, 2013 
  
Recommendation for Margaret E. Roberts   
   
Quick summary: Molly Roberts is enthusiastic and really smart, and I’d deﬁnitely support her. She came to graduate school well trained in methods and statistics, and political science in general, including an MA from Stanford. She seems to survive on an ever increasing diet of new ideas, new methods, new research, and a whole lot of work. From a class of about 75, I chose her to be one of two teaching fellows for the next year. She was so good at being a teaching fellow that I asked her to do it again and she is doing a terriﬁc job. The students love her.    
  
In addition to an excellent technical background, she has deep substantive interests. These include comparative politics, including banking and development policies in East Asia, international political economy, including the politics of non-tariﬀ trade barriers and WTO dispute resolution, and American politics, such as Congressional determinants of trade policy and globalization attitudes in the mass public.    
  
Molly and I are now working together with another student on a project on Chinese and American public opinion expressed in millions of social media posts. We have a feed of all Chinese and English social media posts, harvested from the web in real time and including many that are subsequently taken down by the Chinese government. We’ve adapted methods of automated text analysis to compare expressed opinion in these two countries. Molly knows Chinese well enough to code text herself and direct a team of Chinese coders, knows enough about the issues and interest of the Chinese government to carefully parse Chinese government statements and to select issue for us to track, and understands the technical background enough to make serious methodological contributions too. This work has also blossomed into a large scale study of censorship in China, including analyses of the text censored social media posts, which we have found a way to obtain before the Chinese government manages to take them down.  
  
Here are two illustrations of how committed Molly is to research. First, when she arrived here, she came by and expressed her interest in working as a research assistant with me. As I always do in cases like these, I sent her back to her classes (funding isn’t an issue for admitted students and the time devoted to classes seems valuable for at least the ﬁrst couple of years). She did as I suggested but then came back a few weeks later, and then again, and again, pushing hard to be involved in research. She just had more bandwidth than others, and we’ve been working closely together ever since. Someone who constantly challenges herself is exactly the right proﬁle for someone who will make it a long way. Second, and just as telling: I had two projects I decided she might like to be involved in and oﬀered her the choice. One was a big, exciting, visible project with big public policy implications and for which there would likely be a lot of media interest. The other involved a highly technical statistical programming project involving aspects of ecological inference. I bet 19 of 20 graduate students would choose the ﬁrst. Molly chose the more diﬃcult path, and we will have our ﬁrst paper on ecological inference together shortly.    
  
We don’t often get students like this, but I wish we did; I strongly encourage you to support her. She deserves it and you’ll be as thrilled as I am to work with her. Please contact me if I can provide more details.    
 
 
Sincerely, 
 
 
Gary King 
Albert J. Weatherhead III University Professor 
Director, Institute for Quantitative Social Science 
Harvard University

Members of the Selection Committee;

It is my pleasure to submit a letter of recommendation for Steve Rogers to attend the Society for Political Methodology Summer meetings to present a poster.

Among other projects, Steve is working on extending the "Out of Step" paper of Brady, Canes-Wrone and Cogan both over time and to additional legislatures (i.e., state legislatures).  To do so, he shows that it is possible to derive a more theoretically appropriate specification for the relationship than the one that is used in the APSR paper.  To better model the notion of "out-of-step," he proposed a specification that models the distance between legislators' ideal point and a projected district ideal point rather than simply assume that all "extreme" members are out of step as is done in the original paper.  So doing not only refines the conclusions that we make about the extent of individual level accountability at the national level, but it also provides the ability to compare the amount of accountability across state legislatures.  

A second contribution is to scale the various state legislatures over time and to link them to measures of district preferences to estimate the relationship between these features and electoral returns.

To be clear, while the paper is innovative in terms of arguing for a more theoretically justifiable specification of the estimation equation and while it advances our understanding of the extent to which legislators are held electorally responsible for their individual positions, it is not a novel statistical innovation.  Even so, I hope that you agree that such refinements are an important contribution and worthy of a poster presentation.

Personally, Steve is a very pleasant and sharp individual who would not only benefit greatly from the conference, but who would also make a positive contribution to it.  He is an applied methodologist rather than a "pure" methodologist, but I think that he would bring valuable insights to the discussion and conversations.

Please do not hesitate to let me know if there is any more information I can provide and best of luck in your deliberations.

Best,
Josh Clinton

Dear Committee:
I am writing to give my recommendation to Katelyn Sack for an academic position in your department. 
I known Katelyn extremely well. She took the core American political behavior seminar and the
introductory statistical methods course from me; she served as a teaching assistant in my large 
public opinion lecture course; I am on her dissertation committee; and I have worked closely with 
her in the development of her dissertation research. She is among if not the smartest, most 
creative, and most broadly intellectually curious students I have had the pleasure to work with, 
either here or during my three years at Cornell before coming to UVa in 2006. While she struggles 
at times to focus her work and to connect it clearly with the literatures on which she draws, she 
is also one of the most active and productive graduate students I have known.

She took the statistics course early in her career, when she thought she wanted to be a pure 
political theorist. Nevertheless, she engaged fully with the material and mastered the statistical 
content, all the while coming
to office hours to discuss subtle epistemological implications of different approaches to 
quantifying and analyzing political behavior. This broad engagement and curiosity carried over to 
her work in the behavior seminar, and to her ambitious dissertation project. Katelyn continues to 
have an interest in speaking to questions in political theory; she has married this interest with 
an empirical focus on the intersections of political psychology and public administration, and with 
a deep commitment to explicating—and intervening—in democratic practice on the ground.

Katelyn’s dissertation seeks to explore the important political psychological assumptions that lie 
at the heart of theoretical accounts of the rational administrative state: that rational 
procedures, objectively applied, can help align the myriad small decisions made by street level 
bureaucrats with the broad goals and values articulated by the democratic process. In particular, 
she explores the ways that routine, quantified, and technological administrative procedures and 
techniques, though designed to remove bias from the administration of public policy, can ironically 
perpetuate those very biases while obfuscating the operation
of bias under a cloak of technological sophistication. Her dissertation articulates and explores 
empirically a novel model of the political psychological process by which biases affect seemingly 
objective technologies; in addition, she explores empirically the political development of state 
capacity to deploy these technologies, and the effects of that deployment on agency diversity and 
performance.

As this characterization suggests, Katelyn’s interests and ambition are exceedingly broad. I—and 
the rest of her committee—advised her that her proposal contained at least two or three 
dissertations and that she should scale back to focus on just one. While she has narrowed and 
focused her dissertation considerably, she has maintained her commitment to completing a very 
ambitious project that connects with political psychology, political theory, and American political 
development. I was frankly concerned that this would

be undoable; I have been impressed, or even amazed, over the past two years as Katelyn has dived 
into and mastered very diverse literatures (from experimental design, to details of polygraph 
implementation, to the political development of administrative state, and far more); obtained 
funding from a number of sources, including the NSF; conducted many creative and difficult studies; 
and drafted five dissertation chapters.

Katelyn focuses on most directly on the polygraph, arguing convincingly that far from being an 
obscure technology at the edges of criminal justice, the polygraph’s reach is large and increasing, 
especially with the expansion of the national security state in the decade since 9/11. More 
importantly, she argues that the polygraph symbolizes and embodies the ways that more general 
beliefs in rational techniques distort the very ways we understand human behavior. She argues that 
the polygraph—and related technologies of surveillance and forensic inference—have played an 
important role in shaping the national security and surveillance states, beginning in the 
Progressive Era and accelerating substantially post-9/11.

Her political psychological model seeks to explicate the interactions between two kinds of bias: 
that that exists, often implicitly, in the interpreter—the polygraph examiner, the doctor, the 
social service agency employee—and that that exists in the subject—the polygraph examinee, the 
patient, the welfare client. Her argument is that these can and do interact with each other such 
that their combined effect is potentially greater than either along. Thus, she moves beyond the 
relatively uncontroversial claim that street level bureaucrats may have unconscious biases of 
various sorts that shape their interpretations of the data before them. Thus, Katelyn is bringing 
together insights from the social psychological literatures on unconscious bias, on the one hand, 
and stereotype threat, on the other. And on the third hand, she explores not just the impact of 
this interaction at the micro-level moment of a particular interaction, but also at the aggregate 
level, when micro decisions made over time cumulate to shape, for example, the police agencies that 
rely on the polygraph in hiring.

Katelyn has conducted an extremely broad range of studies to explore these questions, including a 
mail survey of licensed polygraph examiners; an analysis of historical/administrative data on the 
adoption of polygraph technology by law enforcement agencies and the downstream effects on 
diversity and on complaints about brutality; several survey experiments, in which subjects 
recruited on the internet (using mTurk) interact with technological decision aids; and finally, a 
study in which she brought people in to the lab to be poygraphed, in order to document differences 
in physiological responses to the polygraph among different racial and attitudinal (authoritarian 
vs. non-authoritarian) groups.

These studies have produced a blizzard of data that Katelyn has made good progress in analyzing and 
writing up. As with any data collection, the results are messier than our carefully-crafted 
theories might lead us to expect. While she is making good progress in her analysis and writing, I 
do not think she has yet developed the crisp theoretical and empirical story that she needs to make 
the project fully satisfying. That said, I am confident that she will be able to do so over the 
coming months.

Let me say a few words about Katelyn as a teacher. While most of us can talk a reasonable game 
about student-centered instruction, I am struck by the degree to which Katelyn actually implements 
it in her teaching. She is creative and dynamic, as her teaching statement and her evaluations 
attest. I have spoken with a number of undergraduate students in my courses about her as a TA. Of 
course they appreciate the creative in-class projects she uses. However, I can honestly say she is 
the only TA about whom 
undergraduates have said that they valued the extra quizzes she gives in section. I take this as a 
testament to her commitment to her students and to her ability to bring them on board a 
collaborative learning endeavor.

In sum, Katelyn is extremely ambitious and has worked hard to keep a very sprawling project

Dear Selection Committee Member,

I am pleased to recommend Emily Schilling for the 2013 Political Methodology Summer Meeting. 

Schilling is in her third year in the program and stood out from her first semester in the American politics seminar that I taught, partly because of her strong background in economics and math. That summer I asked her to work with me on a new paper that would use spatial modeling and advanced methods. Since then I have had Schilling in two of my methods classes (one on event history and spatial analysis and another on statistical estimation of formal models) and can say that she has a very bright future in methods. She received an A in both classes and recently passed her qualifying exam in methods, posting the second highest score on the written component that I have seen. Further, her paper for the exam is the first I know of here at Iowa that seeks to develop a new estimator rather than merely providing an in-depth explanation and application of an existing method.

In this paper she develops a method for addressing right censoring in spatial duration models. Hays and Kachi (2007) recently developed a spatial duration estimator but only for a fully observed outcome variable. Right censoring creates big problems for spatial models since the outcome for one observation may depend on the outcome for every other observation. Right censoring makes it impossible for the analyst to capture this dependency. Schilling’s paper adapts the imputation methods of Wei and Tanner (1991) for right censoring in nonspatial duration models to create a routine that imputes the right censored outcomes through rejection sampling and then uses these imputed values for estimation. Her Monte Carlo analysis suggests that this approach works, but also that it may be computationally challenging with even moderate amounts of right censoring. Along with Jude Hays, we have proposed a paper that hopes to address these computational issues. Schilling’s poster proposal for the conference seeks to extend these results to develop a competing risks spatial duration estimator, motivated by a substantive paper that she wrote for one of my methods classes that models interdependence in the timing of Senators’ announcing supporting and opposing positions in the case of the NAFTA vote.

Schilling has been involved in a couple of other research projects with me and has proved to be a quick study in terms of picking up new methods, learning new software, and writing code to get estimates. She is in the process of developing her dissertation prospectus, which will likely involve the application of formal theory and methods to Congressional committees and policymaking. 

I believe that Schilling would benefit greatly from the opportunity to attend the summer methods meeting. She is one of our up and coming methods students and is already reaching the point of being more than just a consumer of sophisticated methods. Attending the meeting would be invaluable both to receive feedback on her own work, but also to get exposure to the high quality of research and discussion that occurs at the summer methods meeting.

Please let me know if you any questions.

Frederick J. Boehmke

recommendation:
I have known Brandon Stewart since he took my class in advanced
political methodology in his second semester in graduate school.  The
class had about 80 students from around the university, and he was in
a very small group at the very top of the class.  I chose him to be
one of two teaching fellows for the next year's class.  Almost all of
those who did as well are now prominent faculty at top universities
around the country; I expect he will do as well.

Brandon's paper in my class is very likely to be published in the near
future.  He collected about 90 published articles that use some
measure of ``neighbors'' among countries or states and shows that the
type of arbitrary decision made in each article leads to highly
non-robust results.  He shows how the existing adjacency, interpoint
distance and graph-based approaches offer different theoretical
conceptualizations of neighbors and how almost none of the 90 articles
used more than one specification.  The assignment was to replicate one
article, and he replicated three: all showed the nonrobustness he
hypothesized.  He then went further toward developing a
conceptualization that should enable scholars to make more reliable
progress going forward.

Brandon and I have been working together since he took my class on
some automated visualization techniques for text analysis work.  We
hope to be able to provide some computer-assisted methods for those
who need to read a large volume of text --- everyone from philosophers
to qualitative analysts of archival records to those who conduct
intensive interviews.

Brandon is positioning himself with a unique and highly valuable set
of skills at the intersection of political science, statistics,
automated content analysis, visualization, and computer science.  The
availability of unstructured text is increasing fast: for example,
last year, 10 minutes of worldwide email could fill the entire Library
of Congress, and this year social media updates have surpassed email.
And that of course doesn't count press releases, legislative floor
speeches, and many other official communications by politicians, as
well as many others.  Political scientists are gradually coming to
recognize this mass of information as data; its not in the usual
familiar matrix of numbers, but it as or more informative.  Brandon is
an obvious candidate to help lead this movement.

Brandon is a hard and independent worker.  If you support him, I bet
you'll be proud of the result.  He has my very strong support.  Please
let me know if I can provide any additional information.

recommendation:
To the Committee,

I write to recommend Susanna Supalla for the Political Methodology Summer Conference.  Susanna is a very promising and competent graduate student working on a very interesting dissertation.  Two aspects of her project make it of particular interest to the methods community.  First, money in campaigns flows not only between donors and candidates, but between donors and parties, parties and candidates, and parties and candidates at different levels of government (federal and state).  Some of these connections have been studied individually, but no one has characterized the full system.    Susanna takes on this daunting challenge.  Second, Susanna characterizes the flow of money in campaigns through an innovative use of network analysis.  Where nearly all network analyses in political science are static---they provide nothing more than a snapshot of a system---Susanna describes how money flows between donors, parties, and candidates at the federal and state levels.  Susanna achieved this goal by adapting network tools from outside the discipline, such as those used to analyze internet traffic flows, to political science.  

I think both Susanna and the other attendees will benefit from her presence at the conference.  Please feel free to contact me if I can be of further assistance.  

Sincerely, 

Kevin Clarke

recommendation:
Antonio has been a student in two of my classes and I am a member of his dissertation committee.  I have known Antonio for over four years. He is an excellent student, the equal of any student currently in our graduate program. 

Antonio's thesis addresses fundamental questions about how form of government affects the most basic welfare of citizens. Put simply, Antonio seeks to identify the causal effect of democracy, military dictatorship, and other forms of government on the duration and quality of people's lives.  This is an exceedingly difficult inferential problem.

In the part of the project that he proposes to present at Methods, he draws on a huge set of DHS surveys from around the world and covering some 30 years of childbirths to move inside national average rates of infant mortality to determine to what degree democratic transitions affect the distribution of health outcomes across individual within a country.  Ask for example, if variation in infant mortality across income, class, or ethnic strata is lessened by democracy.

His work is informed by extensive formal training statistics and biostatistics and Antonio is earning his Masters in Statistics as well as his PhD in Political Science. 

Antonio is an impressive young scholar who will be on the job market next fall.  I very much hope that he is able to demonstrate his considerable talent at Methods this summer.

I am writing to recommend Carlos Velasco Rivera who is a fourth year
Ph.D. student at Princeton for the summer methodology conference.
Carlos has completed the four-course quantitative methods sequence at
Princeton and was clearly the best student among about twenty students
of his cohort.  He and I have been working on several projects,
including the project with Gary King which evaluates the electoral
consequences of Seguro Popular, the Mexican universal health insurance
program, using the randomization of program implementation across
villages.  Carlos' primary field is the comparative political economy
and already has two working papers, which I think will be published in
a top journal in the near future.  Over the past two years, he has
presented those two papers and received feedback before submitting
them to journals for publication.  This year, he will be presenting

This is not a trivial task requiring him to write many sophisticated
Python scripts to organize all text information that is either
available on the website or scanned by hand.  Using this unique data
set, he will analyze the origins and consequences of political
dynasties in a democracy.  Carlos is also planning to gether more data
on political dynasties from other countries.  While this project is
still at an early stage, I am hopeful that he will lean some new
insigts from these data he has collected.  In conclusion, Carlos is a
promising graduate student who I predict will become a cutting-edge
scholar of comparative political economy with an impressive set of
technical expertise in quantitative methods.  I urge the program
committee to give him an opportunity to present his research at the
political methodology conference poster session.

recommendation:
Dear PolMeth,

I enthusiastically recommend Yamil Velez to present a poster at your 2013 conference. Yamil is an incredibly bright and talented methodologist – probably the very best to come to Stony Brook in my time here. For example, when he was a second-year student we had him TAing our PhD courses in methods and he will soon be in the classroom teaching our MA methods courses. His breadth of knowledge across experimentation, agent-based modeling, time series, MLE, and on and on is amazing. I expect that when he goes on the market in fall 2014 he will compete for the top jobs in the country.  Yamil’s methods interests are varied and he would get a lot out of the conference. But he would also add a lot with a presentation of his agent based model that is a key part of a fascinating dissertation. At the moment we are all fighting to join his committee – me, Stanley Feldman, Jason Barabas, and Oleg Smirnov have won the battle so far but there are others looking to jump on. Yamil is a pleasure to have in graduate school and we want to do all we can to bring him to the attention of the PolMeth community.

As the Director of Graduate Studies and a member of the PolMeth community I only recommend the poster session to a few of our students. For example, last year we did not recommend it to anyone. This year, Yamil is a no-brainer. I know that attendance at the conference is limited but I hope you can find room for Yamil. 

Thank you,
Matt Lebo

recommendation:
CONFIDENTIAL LETTER OF RECOMMENDATION FOR MELINDA WHITE:

I am writing to recommend Melinda White, an applicant to attend POLMETH. Mindy is in her fifth semester of a Ph.D. program in political science as I write. She came highly recommended and has done excellent work. She did her B.A. work at Texas A&M, where she worked closely with Paul Kellstedt. She will finish an M.A. thesis under my direction. She is writing on the use of Markov models and related smoothing techniques for time series produced by automated text analysis systems.

Mindy also served as my research assistant during summer, 2012. Her task was to explore opportunities for computerized content analyses using the PYTHON language as a tool. She made amazing progress, working totally without direction (while I was out of the country). I was very impressed. That work is now being incorporated in a collaborative Midwest paper.

Mindy has completed, with flying colors, the demanding methods sequence here at UNC. She is a natural, the kind of person---not like me---who finds advanced work easy. She is now finishing my time series seminar. She intends to do work in our Statistics Department for an MA in addition to her political science degrees.

In sum, Mindy White is an outstanding prospect for POLMETH and I give her my highest recommendation. She will benefit from the meeting and it will benefit from her attendance.

Sincerely,
  

James A. Stimson
Raymond Dawson Bicentennial Distinguished Professor

Just to get my toe over the deadline line, I will strongly recommend (and fund) two other applicants, Elizabeth Coggins (who will post-doc with Andrew Martin this year) and Brice Acree, a first year student here.

Dear selection committee,

I write today in support of Ahra Wu's application to attend the 2013 Annual Meeting of the Society for Political Methodology.

Ahra is a co-author on the project that I have proposed to present at this year's POLMETH, "Assessing and Correcting Publication Bias." Ahra has been a full participant in all aspects of this project, and I would like her to be there if we get the chance to present our paper at POLMETH (though I will handle the presentation itself). I'd also like to give her the opportunity to consider her own career opportunities in political methodology at the conference.

Ahra is a careful, methodical, and intelligent scholar with a high level of mathematical preparation. In classwork at Rice, she has consistently demonstrated an excellent command over high-level material and an excellent attention to detail. I expect her to make the most of her time at POLMETH, to be a fully engaged member of the audience at relevant panels, and to make new and mutually beneficial connections with other attendees. 

In summary, I give Ahra my full support and strongly urge you to accept her application to attend POLMETH. If you need any additional information about Ahra, please feel free to contact me at 678-383-9629 or justin@justinesarey.com.

Very respectfully,

Dr. Justin Esarey
Assistant Prof. of Political Science
Rice University
